Overhand and underhand are terms used in baseball to describe the motion of a pitch.

Baseball is a bat-and-ball game played between two opposing teams who take turns batting and fielding. The game proceeds when a player on the fielding team, called the pitcher, throws a ball which a player on the batting team tries to hit with a bat.
Overhand is when the pitcher releases the ball above shoulder level.

In baseball, a pitch is the act of throwing a baseball toward home plate to start a play. The term comes from the Knickerbocker Rules. Originally, the ball had to be literally "pitched" underhand, as with pitching horseshoes. Overhand throwing was not allowed until 1884.
The ball was thrown overhand.

In baseball, a pitch is the act of throwing a baseball toward home plate to start a play. The term comes from the Knickerbocker Rules. Originally, the ball had to be literally "pitched" underhand, as with pitching horseshoes.

A pitch is the throw of a baseball toward home plate to start a play. The pitcher releases the ball from his glove, hand or fingers toward home plate, where the catcher catches it to retire a batter, to start a play or a run.

In baseball, the pitcher is the player who throws the baseball from the pitcher's mound toward the catcher to begin each play, with the goal of retiring a batter, who attempts to either make contact with the pitched ball or draw a walk.
Pitching is the throwing of a baseball by a player for a teammate to try to hit.
The baseball player is swinging at a ball thrown overhand.
The pitcher throws the ball from the pitcher's mound toward the hitter. The ball is thrown in a high arc to the plate, where the batter, with any luck, hits it.
A baseball pitcher uses an overhand throwing motion to pitch the ball.
